If ... is not ...

overview.problemStatement:
Forum

Is it true that the number of graphs on $n$ vertices which do not contain $G$ is\[\leq 2^{(1+o(1))\mathrm{ex}(n;G)}?\]



If $G$ is not bipartite the answer is yes, proved by Erd\H{o}s, Frankl, and R\"{o}dl \cite{EFR86}. The answer is no for $G=C_6$, the cycle on 6 vertices. Morris and Saxton \cite{MoSa16} have proved there are at least\[2^{(1+c)\mathrm{ex}(n;C_6)}\]such graphs for infinitely many $n$, for some constant $c>0$. It is still possible (and conjectured by Morris and Saxton) that the weaker bound of\[2^{O(\mathrm{ex}(n;G))}\]holds for all $G$.




References


[EFR86] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Frankl, P. and R\"{o}dl, V., The asymptotic number of graphs not containing a fixed subgraph and a problem for hypergraphs having no exponent. Graphs Combin. (1986), 113-121.

[MoSa16] Morris, Robert and Saxton, David, The number of $C_{2\ell}$-free graphs. Adv. Math. (2016), 534-580.
